"Wonderwall" is an excellent choice! Learning songs you enjoy is a great way to stay motivated, and analyzing iconic chord progressions can help you understand music theory in a more practical way. I'd recommend a hybrid approach: learn the song, and then dig deeper into the theory behind it. Here's a step-by-step approach to help you get the most out of it:

**Learn the song:**

1. Start by learning the chords and strumming pattern of "Wonderwall." You can find many online resources, including tablature, chord charts, and video tutorials.
2. Focus on playing the song smoothly, with a good rhythm and chord changes.

**Analyze the chord progression:**

1. Once you're comfortable playing the song, take a closer look at the chord progression. "Wonderwall" uses a variation of the I-V-vi-IV progression, which is a very common and popular progression.
2. Identify the chords used in the song: G - D - Em - C - G (I - V - vi - IV - I). Try to understand how these chords relate to each other and the key of the song (G major).
3. Experiment with playing each chord individually, focusing on the root note and the intervals within each chord. This will help you develop a deeper understanding of how the chords function.

**Dive into music theory:**

1. Learn about the I-V-vi-IV progression and its variations. This progression is commonly used in pop and rock music, and understanding its structure will help you analyze and create your own chord progressions.
2. Study the key of G major and its corresponding chords (I - V - vi - IV - VII). Learn how the chords are built and how they relate to each other.
3. Explore the concept of chord functions: tonic (I), dominant (V), subdominant (IV), and relative minor (vi). This will help you understand why certain chords sound good together and how to create harmonic tension and resolution.

**Apply your knowledge:**

1. Try creating your own variations of the I-V-vi-IV progression using different keys and chord voicings.
2. Experiment with substituting chords or adding seventh chords to create more complex harmonies.
3. Apply your knowledge to other songs you enjoy, analyzing their chord progressions and understanding how they work.

By following this approach, you'll develop a solid understanding of chord progressions, music theory, and how to apply them to your guitar playing. Remember, the key is to practice regularly and have fun exploring the world of music theory!
